prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 3mm Mosaic
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Mosaic of the 3mm dust continuum emission in the G10.32-0.13 IR bubble

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The two goals of the 3mm mosaic are: 1. To determine the distribution of thermal dust emission and ionized gas in the bubble rim (the latter requiring information from longer wavelength observations with the ATCA). 2. To determine the extent and origin of any outflows associated with the young high-mass YSOs through observations of HCO+ and SiO.
The requested resolution of 1.5 arcseconds corresponds to a linear scale of 7500 AU at the distance to the source (4.95 kpc). It is approximately the same as the MIR GLIMPSE data (and we will obtain 12mm and 7mm observations at this resolution from ATCA observations). This resolution is required to for SED modeling of the individual dust clumps associated with the high-mass YSOs.
The BGPS 1.1 mm continuum emission integrated over the entire bubble rim is approximately 110 Jy. Assuming a dust emissivity of 1.7 (in the middle of the typical range observed for high-mass star formation regions) we expect an integrated flux density of approximately 3 Jy at 3 mm due to thermal dust emission, with a similar contribution due to free-free emission. Were this emission uniformly distributed over the mosaic region the predicted 3 mm intensity would be 0.36 mJy/beam (i.e. at the 3.6 sigma level). The emission will be clumpy, rather than uniformly distributed, hence at the requested sensitivity we expect to be able to detect all the clumps within the bubble rim.
The primary line target is the HCO+ (1-0) transition. From MALT90 observations (40 arcsecond angular resolution) the HCO+ (1-0) emission towards the high-mass YSOs peaks at between 2.2 and 2.8K with a typical FWHM of 3 km/s. For a 1.5 arcsecond angular resolution and 39 seconds onsource per mosaic pointing the RMS in a 0.4 km/s spectral channel of 0.03 Jy (corresponding to 2.1 K in a 1.5 arcsecond beam), assuming 7th octile water vapour conditions. Assuming that much of the HCO+ emission originates angular scales of less 12 arcseconds (see for example HCO+ interferometric observations by Gomez et al., 1999, ApJ, 514, 287) then the peak intensity observed by ALMA will be a factor of more than 10 higher than the MALT90 peak and will be detected with a signal to noise ratio greater than 10. The H13CO+ line peak observed by MALT90 are typically a factor of 4-5 weaker than the HCO+ peak, while the HCN (1-0) ranges from 1-2.2 K and the SiO is an order of magnitude weaker. We will use the MALT90 data to determine the short-spacing flux for these lines, although this is not necessary to achieve our primary science goals which depend only on the compact emission.
Where necessary we will use spectral and/or spatial smoothing to reliably detect emission from the different lines. We do not expect this to be necessary for the HCO+ or HCN data, but it may be required for H13CO+ and SiO, which are significantly weaker.
We have included observations of a number of other "hot-core" tracer molecules (e.g. HCCN and CH3OH) which lie in the same band as the primary target lines and can be accommodated within the correlator limitations. Some of these lines are at the edge of the observable band, but as they are not the primary transitions this will have no impact on the science goals of the project.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 1mm mosaic core A
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Mosaic of the 1mm dust and line emission towards G10.32-0.13 YSO A

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The two goals of the 1mm mosaics are: 1. To determine the properties of dust emission associated with the high-mass YSOs. 2. To see if there is any evidence for infalling gas towards the centre of the molecular cores through observations of HCO+ (3-2).
The requested resolution of 1.5 arcseconds corresponds to a linear scale of 7500 AU at the distance to the source (4.95 kpc). It is approximately the same as the MIR GLIMPSE data (and we will obtain 12mm and 7mm observations at this resolution from ATCA observations). This resolution is required to for SED modeling of the individual dust clumps associated with the high-mass YSOs.
The BGPS 1.1 mm continuum emission integrated over the entire bubble rim is approximately 110 Jy. With an RMS in the 1.1 mm ALMA mosaics of 0.3 mJy (10 seconds onsource per mosaic point) we will be sensitive to all compact cores with a mass greater than approximately 0.3 solar masses. This will enable us to investigate the distribution of clump masses throughout the bubble rim, and in particular accurately determine the mass of the YSO associated clumps.
The primary line target is the HCO+ (3-2) transition. From pointed H13CO+ (3-2) observations by He et al. (2012) with 30 arcsecond resolution towards several locations within the G10.32-0.13 bubble, we estimate the HCO+ brightness on these scales to be approximately 10-20K (assuming HCO+:H13CO+ abundance ratio of 50:1). The emission from higher excitation lines such as HCO+(3-2) will be generally be on smaller scales than the HCO+ (1-0), so we expect the line peak to be significantly stronger at 1.5 arcsecond resolution than at 30 arcsecond resolution and that we easily be able to detect it with an RMS sensitivity in a single (0.3 km/s) spectral channel of 0.1 Jy (corresponding to 6.8 K in a 1.5 arcsecond beam),assuming 4th octile water vapour conditions. The same argument applies for the HCN(3-2) emission.
Where necessary we will use spectral and/or spatial smoothing to reliably detect emission from the different lines. We do not expect this to be necessary for the HCO+ or HCN data.
We have included observations of a number of other "hot-core" and outflow tracer molecules (e.g. SO and CH3OH) which lie in the same band as the primary target lines and can be accommodated within the correlator limitations.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Mosaic of the 1mm dust and line emission towards G10.32-0.13 YSOs C & D

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Infrared bubbles form when stellar winds and radiation pressure from young high-mass stars sweep up material from the parent molecular cloud, and can trigger the formation of a second generation of stars at the bubble rim. The 'collect and collapse' model of triggered star formation suggests that new stars are produced when compression of swept up material causes fragmentation under self-gravity. Alternatively, pre-existing molecular cores may undergo `monolithic' collapse triggered by the bubble shock. We have recently undertaken a detailed study of triggered star formation in the rim of the infrared bubble G10.32-0.13 located in the W31 star formation region. The measured age and mass of the molecular cores hosting the young stellar objects (YSOs) are not consistent with the predictions of collect and collapse. These YSOs represent the best candidates yet identified for molecular cores in the process of forming high-mass stars through monolithic collapse. In this proposal we seek to determine the mass distribution and kinematics of the molecular gas in this region to directly test if they are consistent with the expectations of the monolithic collapse model.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: School of Mathematics and Physics, University of Tasmania

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: School of Mathematics and Physics, University of Tasmania
Astronomy and Space Science, Australia Telescope National Facility
